div1.head:
Richmond Dispatch
by Cowardin & Hammersley.
div1.p:
the Daily Dispatch is served to subscribers at six and A Quarter Cents per Week, payable to the Carrier weekly.
Price for mailing, $4 a year, or $2.50 for six months, in advance.
the Semi-Weekly Dispatch is issued every Tuesday and Friday at $2.00, in advance.
the Weekly Dispatch is issued every Friday, and mailed to subscribers at $1 per annum.
Advertisements published until forbid, will be charged 50 cents per square of eight lines for the first insertion, and 25 cents for each continuance

div3.head: The Signs from the North.
div3.p:
In this paper of yesterday there appeared a statement of a rumor that certain gentlemen from Illinois and Indiana had arrived here on a mission of a friendly and peaceful nature.
We are unable to any how-much truth there is in the rumor, but we should not be surprised to learn at any day that inquiries had come from that portion of the Northwest to our Government, to ascertain its feelings and dispositions with reference to our future relations with the States of the Upper Mississippi Valley.
So far as the world knows, however, there has yet been no action in those States to give very great solemnity or authority to any mission of that sort alluded to.

The rapid spread of the hostility to the Federal Administration in the Northwest; the speedy increase there of bitter opposition to the war of Abolition, and hatred to New England, is — though entirely natural and consistent with the interests of the communities — nevertheless surprising.
The boldness and power of the demonstration, so soon after Abolitionism had carried everything before it, and erected its power to intolerantly and defiantly in that vast region, betokens an extraordinary revolution.
We can hardly suppose a demonstration displaying such vigor, and one so entirely in harmony with public interest, will be easily checked, or, indeed, that it will be checked at all until it achieves the consequences to which it tends with irresistible force, viz: a separation of the States of the Upper Mississippi Valley from the Atlantic States of the Federal Government, and the erection of a great interior empire, having free and unrestricted outlets for commerce to the Gulf via the Mississippi, and to the Atlantic via the Lakes and the St. Lawrence, with Chicago as its grand commercial capital.

Having anticipated this as one of the results of this war from its beginning, the recent indications referred to more than ever confirm us in the opinion.
Upon them, moreover, we have relied in a great measure in our hopes of a short war.

It is impossible, if they are not entirely delusive, for the Federal Administration to treat them with indifference — nay, not to be influenced by them — The Northwest is the main dependence of Yankeedom in this war, both for men and supplies.
If that withdraws from it there is no recourse but to abandon the war itself altogether and to let the South go. Driven to desperation, the Federal Government would deem that probably the only mode of saving the Northwest.
But whenever that great country forced the abandonment of the war it will compel the Atlantic States to submit to a second dissolution.
Its public sentiment is unmistakable.

The "Pan-Handle" of Virginia is the wedge that will make this great split.
That narrow ship of land has been denounced and derided for disloyalty, and for its shape and appearance.
Let it be elevated to a high place in our consideration and affections.
We know it to be less oral than it is represented to be; and if it divides the ruthless power that is now invading us and splits off its better part to be our friends, why, let us consider.
It a beautiful and a delightful spot of earth--one of the dearest parts of Virginia.
For such a favor to mankind, all should say God bless the Panhandle!

The circumscribed limits of half a sheet shuts out from our columns a great deal of matter of public interest, and compels us very much to abbreviate that which is published.
The eulogies pronounced in Congress upon the announcement of the death of Senator Preston were among the former; but we have this morning made room for the appropriate address of Mr. Staples on that occasion.
We select his from the number of excellent speeches because Mr. S. is the representative of Mr. Preston's district — nay, resides in the same county where the distinguished Senator lived, and was a law partner of his.

div3.head: Indiana.
div3.p:
--The Tribune of the 7th, and the Cincinnati Commercial, announce the discovery of a plot to separate the Northwest from the Yankee Government.
It is said to have been suppressed by Gov. Morton in Indiana.
The correspondent of the Commercial alleges that this treason was hatched by, and is unextensive with, the K. G. C. organization.
Governor Morton prevented the seizure of the State Arsenal at Indianapolis.

div4.p: --The Senate was called to order at 12 o'clock by the Lieut. Governor, and opened with prayer by Rev. Dr. Edwards.

div4.head: Resolutions of Inquiry.
div4.p:
--By Mr. Christian, of Augusta; Of so amending the Code of Virginia as to authorize sheriffs to return delinquent lists for militia fines to the County Court during the war. Adopted.
By Mr. Whittle: Of authorizing impressment of articles necessary for the supports of the families of soldiers when the same are supported by law; and also for the support of the inmates of aims-houses; that they report, also, a plan for the proper valuation of such articles as may be impressed.
Adopted. By Mr. Braunont Of reporting a bill to provide for the temporary care and support of lunatics who cannot be cared for at the Central Lunatic Asylum.
Adopted. By Mr. Branch; Of amending the Code so as to allow slaves, as well as other property seized under attachment, to be sold by order of the Court, if in the opinion of the Court, it be proper.
Adopted.
A bill to convert into stock, to be held by the State, the interest in arrear due by the State to the South-Side Railroad, was reported by the committee.
Mr. Dickinson, of Prince Edward, submitted a report from the Committee on Federal Relations, touching the arrest of citizens and concerning martial law. Made the order of the day for to-morrow.

Mr. Coghill moved that the bill to amend the first, third, fourth, and seventh sections of "An act to provide for the public defence," be made the special order for to-day.
Adopted.
The bill allowing the Governor three Aids, with the rank of Lieutenant-Colonel, was so amended as to grant pay but to one, which shall be that of Captain of cavalry, and passed.
The Senate refused to take up the resolution to adjourn on the 7th of February.

A bill to repeal the Fence law was passed.
[It gives discretionary power to the Justices of County Courts to dispense with fences in certain counties therein named]
On motion of Mr. Whittle, the Senate adjourned.

div4.head: House of Delegates.
div4.p: --The House met at 12 o'clock and was opened with prayer by Rev. Dr. Burrows.

The Senate returned with amendment House bill exempting from active military service, under the proclamation of the Governor of the 10th of January, 1863, or under proclamation such portions as may have furnished substitutes in the Confederate army for three years or the war.--The amendment provides that such exempts may be called into service for a period not longer than sixty days.
Mr. Edmunds moved that the House disagree to the amendment, which, after some discussion, was agreed to.

The Senate further amended the so as to conscript all substitutes who have or may hereafter become liable to the operation of that act since the date of their substitution; which was also disagreed to.
Mr. Kauffman offered a resolution, which was agreed to, inquiring into the expediency of amending the act refunding money paid as commutation in the army.
Mr. Mallory submitted the following resolution:

q.p:
Resolved, That the Governor of this Commonwealth be requested to inform this House whether or not Dr. Gibson now holds the position of Surgeon General of this State, what salary he receives, and to furnish to this.
House the names and salaries of all other military officers, including Quartermasters, Paymasters, and Commissaries, now paid by the State of Virginia, exclusive of the forces under the command of Gen. Floyd.

div4.p: Mr. Mallory stated that he had been informed by gentlemen on this floor that Dr. Gibson was holding the office of Surgeon General at a salary of $5100 per annum, with nothing to do. His subject in offering this resolution was to ascertain whether such was the fact.

Mr. Anderson, of Botetourt, who was referred to by Mr. Mallory, said he possessed no personal acknowledge of the matter — his information was amply has been gained in conversation with members of the Legislature and others.
The resolution was agreed to.

The hour having arrived for the consideration of the order of the day, (the suppression of exertion,) that bill was taken up and the of the session consumed in its discussion--Mr. Anderson, of Botetourt, advocating and Mr. Hunter, of Jefferson, opposing its provisions.
At 3 o'clock Mr. Hunter suspended his remarks for the purpose of allowing Mr. Grattan to move an adjournment; which motion prevailed, and the House adjourned accordingly.

--The Senate was called to order at 12 o'clock Mr. Hunter in the chair.
Prayer by the Rev. Mr. Peterkin, of the Episcope Church.

Mr. Barnwell, of S. C., from the Committee of reported a bill "to provide for the further issue of Treasury Notes." accompanied by a report forth the views of the committee.
On motion of Mr. Yancey, of Ala., the bill was ordered to be printed.

On motion of Mr. of Louisiana, the Committee of the Infantry was instructed to inquire into the propriety of so amending the present laws as to require the publication of the laws in three newspapers in each State, without requiring that they should be published at the seat of government of each State.

The Senate resumed the consideration of the bill to organize the Supreme Court of the Confederate States. Mr. Semmes, of La., having the floor proceeded to address the Senate at some length, and was followed by Mr. Yancey, of Ala.
After which the Senate adjourned.

div4.head: House of Representatives.
div4.p: --House met at 12 o'clock, and was opened with prayer by Rev. Dr. Moore.

Mr. Dupre, of La., offered a bill to amend an act entitled an act relating to the prepayment of postage in certain cases.
Referred.
Mr. Dupre also offered a resolution that the members of this House draw again for seats in this hall on the 30th day of January, 1863.
This resolution, after some discussion, was agreed to, and the House proceeded to draw for seats under it.

Mr. Dargan, of Ala., offered a resolution that when the House adjourn to-day it adjourn to meet at 12 o'clock on Monday.
Agreed to — ayes 47, noes 34.

The House then went into Committee of the Whole, (Mr. Curry, of Ala., in the chair,) and took up the Exemption bill.
The question was announced to be upon the amendment of Mr. Russell, of Va., to the amendment of Mr. Gartrell, of Ga., so as to make the latter amendment read as follows: "And, provided further. That no person shall be enrolled who has a substitute in the army, furnished in accordance with orders heretofore issued by the Secretary of War, unless the substitute has deserted, or shall desert, or has become or shall become himself liable to military service."

Mr. Russell being entitled to the floor, addressed the House in support of his amendment.
After some further discussion of the subject, the House adjourned.

div3.head: Execution of a deserter.
div3.p:
--Another military execution took place yesterday at Camp Lee, near this city — the party being John Mulligan, of company C, 5th Virginia Cavalry, convicted of deserting on several occasions from his company, and sentenced to be shot.
The various reprieves granted the prisoner expired on yesterday.
Mulligan started from Castle Thunder at 11 o'clock in a hack, being accompanied by two spiritual advisers and two detectives, two of the latter also riding by the side of the conveyance.
There were about 1,200 soldiers present at Camp Lee, including 200 of the City Battalion, under Major Elliott, the whole being drawn up in three sides of a square.
On the arrival of the condemned at the Camp, the hack containing him was driven to the lace appointed for the execution, where the squad detailed from the President's Guard to carry the sentence into effect was also assembled.--Mulligan throughout bore himself quietly and coolly, and seemed to be wholly unembarrassed — After a few minutes spent in conversation with the priest, during which time the guns of the firing party were loaded, Mulligan was asked if he had any request to make or anything to say. He replied "nothing" to both interrogatories.
The band age was then tied around his face and he knelt down.
The firing party had been brought to a "" by a wave of the hand of the officer in charge, and then a similar motion caused the discharge of the guns, when the culprit fell on his face, dead.
He was struck by five balls, three entering his breast, one passing through his heart, and one through his mouth.
The spectacle being had for the sake of the example, in accordance with military usage the troops on the ground were marched by the body in slow time, after which it was put in a coffin and given in charge of the undertaker.

div3.head: Two deserters to be shot.
div3.p:
--Privates Michael Kicrous and James, Broderick, of the Letcher Artillery, were tried before the Court-Martial yesterday for desertion, and were found guilty, two-thirds of the Court concurring in said sentence.
The Commanding General of the Department of Henrico approved the proceedings the findings, and sentences of the Court in these cases, and ordered that the condemned men be shot to death with musketry, at Camp Lee, on Friday, February 6th, between the hours of 8 and 3 o'clock P. M., under the direction of the Provost Marshal of Richmond.

div3.head: Attempting to get a passport by Improper Means.
div3.p:
--A man named John O'Brien was taken in custody yesterday at the office of the Provost Marshal on the charge of attempting to get a passport on the strength of a forged order purporting to be signed by J. Dooley.
O'Brien was carried to the Military Prison of the Western District, where he was given in charge of Captain Booker and locked up for examination.

div3.head: The Abolition prisoners.
div3.p:
--Seven Abolition prisoners arrived at the Libby Prison yesterday.
They were sent down by the Provost Marshal of Gordonsville, having been taken in custody at various times and places by Gen. Hampton's cavalry.
Three of the men belonged to a New York cavalry regiment; two to the 20th Indiana regiment; one to the 2d battalion U. S. Regulars, and one to a Pennsylvania cavalry regiment.
Owing to the non arrival of the boat, none of the prisoners will start for City Point this morning.

div3.head: Prison Items.
div3.p:
--The following arrivals were chronicled at the Libby prison yesterday, James Simms, sent from the Lobby prison by Capt. Turner; Robert Clark and Lewis Armstrong, supposed deserters; H. S. Jenes 19th Va. bat; J. R. Duff, 37th Va., and A. W. Colums, 9th Texas, sent to Capt. Booker for medical treatment; Conrad Selesher, Caskie's artillery, deserter.
The following were discharged yesterday: James Needham sent to his company; T. Wilkinson delivered to Capt. Hawley, and J. R. Kemp, delivered to Col. Page, by order of Gen. Winder.

div3.head: Contraband goods seized.
div3.p:
--Captain George Wright, of the Provost Marshal's detective corps, seized yesterday, at the Fredericksburg Depot, three barrels, two boxes, and one keg of articles that were being transported to the army, supposed to be sutlers' stores, that had obtained admission on the Government train without proper authority.
They were deposited in the Government warehouse, in charge of Captain Moffit, to await explanations by their owner.

div3.head: Arrests.
div3.p:
--The city police yesterday arrested sundry individuals, among them Thos. Turpin, a lad, for stealing $50 from David Smith.
This boy has been under arrest and in the city jail a half dozen times for acts of theft.
John Bulger was taken off the sidewalk drunk by officer Crone, and also conducted to the rage.

div3.head: The streets.
div3.p:
--The recent very disagreeable weather left the streets of this city and the avenues leading to it in such bad condition that travel has been seriously interfered with.
Yesterday a miniature hurricane came to the relief of the people, and by much blowing succeeded in rendering the streets in a passable condition.
It will take a week of good weather to restore the country roads to their pristine condition.

div3.head: Court Proceeding.
div3.p: --David McGrain and H. W. Myers, two soldiers, were brought up and required to answer for disturbing the public peace by fighting together in the neighborhood of the Old Market on Thursday evening.

The case of John A. Johnson, a lad, charged with stealing a uniform coat from Wm. B. Wrenn, was called, but the party who is alleged to have lost the article did not appear, and the examination was continued until Monday.

James G. Duffy, Baptist Dennis, and Chas. Johnson, were arraigned for making an assault on Thos. Moser, and violently and by force despoiling him of $62 in C. S. Treasury notes.
The robbery on this instance occurred at the restaurant of Baptist Dennis, on 17th street, on Thursday evening. The evidence of the witness, which was not controverted made out a pretty clear case, and the three defendants were accordingly committed, to appear before the Hustings Court for further examination.

Sarah Tucker and Sarah Thompson, abandoned white females--one from Hanover county, Va., and one from North Carolina--were committed to jail for associating with negroes.
Their negro friends got 32 lashes each.

John Doyle, arrested on Wednesday on the charge of forging the signature of Dr. H. W. Davis to a requisition on the Quartermaster C. S. A., for one hundred and eighty dollars, was called up and underwent an examination touching the offence of which he stood charged.
After hearing a number of witnesses the Mayor committed the defendant for his appearance before the Hustings Court.
William, slave of William Barrott, was adjudged guilty of stealing a pair gaiters from Harvey &-- of the value of $25, and was ordered twenty five lashes for his flagitious attempt.
Isarah Harlow, a free negro, found on the street without his free papers and drunk, was ordered fifteen lashes and committed for want of a register.
Miles, slave of Charles M. Pleasants, and Mary Jane, slave of Elizabeth Hall, were committed for going at large.
Armstead, slave of Henry J. Corbell, was ordered five lashes for smoking a cigar in the street.

Richard, slave of John H. Williams, was ordered fifteen lashes for going about without a pass.
He had three on his person, but none in his own name.

The case of Mary Vanderlip and Owen Riley was called up. A few days ago Riley Mrs. Vanderlip up for shooting a pistol ball at his person, on Broad street. When the case was called Mrs. Vanderlip entered a counter charge against Riley, to the effect that she was induced to shoot at him because he had made an indecent assault on her person.
On hearing this the Mayor adjourned the examination until to-day, when Mrs. Vanderlip appeared and owners she was mistaken in saying that Riley had attempted personal violence.
The Mayor thereupon required her to give security for her good behavior, and ball for her appearance to answer an indictment for perjury and for firing a pistol an Owner Riley.
She was committed in default of security.

div3.head:
Latest from the North.
Burnside resigned!
be 18 superceded by "Lighting Jon Hocker."

argument.p: Franklin and Sumner charged with Demoralizing the Army and Rellaven from command — Burnside's farewell address — Preposition to call out the militia, &c., &c.

div4.head: [from our own reporter.]
div4.p: --The Philadelphia Inquirer and New York Herald, of the 27th inst., were received here late yesterday.
Gen. Amrose P. Burnside has resigned the command of the Army of the Potomac, and Gen. Joseph Hooker has been appointed to the command.
Gens. Sumner and Franklin, who ranked Hooker, have been relieved from their commands.
In consequence of these changes in the army gold in New York, which opened at 143.35, rose to 152¼ and closed at 15¼. Foreign Exchange is quoted at 166¾.
Burnside will spend a month in New York with his staff.

Another dispatch in the Inquirer says that Franklin and Sumner were charged with "something skin to actual demoralization of the army." Sumner asked to be relieved, which was promptly granted.
We do not learn whether Franklin will be court-martialed or not.

Burnside went down on Sunday to turn over the command to Hooker.
The following is his farewell address:

div5.head:
Hdq'rs Army of the Potomac,
Camp near Falmouth, Jan. 26.
div5.p: By direction of the President of the United States the commanding General this day transfers the command of this army to Major Gen. Joseph Hooker.

The short time that he has directed your movements has not been fruitful of victory or any considerable advancement of our lines; but it has again demonstrated an amount of courage, patience, and endurance, that under more favorable circumstances would have accomplished great results.
Continue to exercise these virtues be true in your devotion to your country and the principles you have sworn to maintain, give to the brave and skillful General who has long been identified with your organization, and who is now to command you, your full and cordial support and co-operation, and you will deserve success.

Your General, in taking an affectionate leave of the army, from which he separates with so much regret, may be pardoned if he bids an especial farewell to his long and tried associates of the Ninth Corps.
His prayers are that God may be with you and grant you continual success until the rebellion is crushed.
div5.closer:
By command of
Major-General Burnside.
Lewis Richmond, A. A. G.

div5.p: Among those who left with Burnside are Major General Park, Chief of Staff; General Patrick, Provost Marshal-General, and Lieutenant Colonel Richmond, Assistant Adjutant General.
When Burnside and Sumner arrived in Washington they were received with rapturous cheers.

The Herald presumes that General Burnside's "modest estimate of his own capacities has had as much to do with this change as any other cause;" regrets that McClellan was not recalled; but says "no doubt Hooker will be cordially received by the men as their leader."
Gen. Wheeler destroyed two cars on Sunday on the Nashville and Franklin Railroad.
Rosecrans complains that newspapers in Louisville announce the shipment of supplies for his army, and thus the rebels hear of them and capture them.
The Hatteras, was sunk in nine fathom water by the Alabama, Creto, or Harriet Lane, which represented herself to be the British war steamer Spitfire, and "sunk her by a heavy fire."

In the House, Monday, Thad, Stevens reported a bill authorizing the President to raise and equip, for five pears' service, one hundred and fifty thousand negro soldiers.
The expediency was inquired into to authorize the President to accept for three years any companies of soldiary that may offer, without limitation as to number.

The Herald has a severe article on Callicott, who was a Democrat, but was a Republican candidate, and beat Trimmer, (Democrat) Vote 61 to 59.--Corruption is alleged, and an investigation asked for. The Herald advises him to cheat the Republicans by going back to the Democrats.

The Herald thinks Burnside's resignation will prevent an early advance, and urges upon Lincoln that time, at this crisis, is precious beyond all calculation.
Three rebel cruisers must be dispersed within three months. Bragg and Vicksburg may fall, "but in Virginia, where success is most essential and our forces overwhelming, it remains in doubt. " "There are strange rumors that the Army of the Potomac is to be broken up and that the 'heart of the rebellion' is to be abandoned for some new expeditions against its extremities."

q.p: "The present Administration, the Government of the United States, and the loyal States of the Union, will be forever disgraced before the world if they fall to accomplish the restoration of the Union.--We must make sure of its accomplishment, too before the first of May, or we are threatened by the Abolition faction with an inglorious dissolution.--It seems incredible that doubts are entertained at Washington of our final success.

"Leading members of the Radical party, foreseeing that the people will refuse them further supplies of men or money, will push forward the campaign with all possible vigor during the next three months. The principle of concentration is to be carried out generally in our military arrangements.
Heavy reinforcements are to be sent to Rosecrans.
Vicksburg and Port Hudson are to be attacked by forces sufficient for their reduction.
Wilmington, Charleston, Savannah, and Mobile are to be assailed in succession, and another effort is to be made to attack the rebel Capital.

"All these objects accomplished, it is expected that by the 1st of May next the rebels will be brought to terms.
While the proposed plan is being carried out, secret agents are to be sent by the Government to Europe for the purpose of coming to an understanding with Louis Napoleon in the event of its failure.
The intention in that case is to call on the French Emperor to interfere to effect a peaceable separation between the North and the South, provided that such separation be based on a plan of gradual emancipation in both sections and a proper adjustment of boundaries.
It is not believed that the South will consent to such terms, and the idea is that its refusal would so damage its cause in Europe that it will fall to secure further sympathy or assistance in that quarter."

div5.p:
Senator Wilson has proposed a bill in the Senate providing for a National Guard of 250,000 men, to be raised pro rata in the several States from the militia between the ages of 21 and 35.
The force is to be divided into 200 regiments, to be officered by the Governors of the several States, and subject to all orders from the President.

div4.head: From Mexico.
div4.p:
Four French war vessels bombarded Acapulco for three days, commencing on the 16th.
The fire was returned from the fort.
The people abandoned the town--thirteen wore killed.
The fort was finally silenced, when 100 sailors landed and spiked the guns.
The fleet then left.

div4.head:
[from the Southern Association.]
additional from the North.
div4.p:
--The Philadelphia Inquirer, of the 28th instant, has been received--[From the news contained in this paper the date evidently should be the 27th, the same as that given by our own reporter.] A dispatch from Stafford Court-House, dated the 25th instant says that the 12th (Slocum's,) and 11th corps are quartered there, and the Reserve Grand Division.
At Wind mill Point three miles below Aquia Creek, hospital accommodations for 500 men have been prepared.
The dispatch adds:

The roads are filled with stragglers and deserters, indicating great demoralization.
The men wind exchange or throw away their clothing and arms, in many instance, and evade the guard by representations of being citizens.

The Philadelphia Inquirer, sarcastically commenting on Burnside's previous avowals of his incapacity to manage so large a body of men, rays their truth has "been verified by the experience of the past two month; the nation will give him credit for frankness instead of want had been set down to the account of his modesty." A brilliant career is predicted for Hooker.
The Washington correspondent of the same paper states that 'the appointment of Hooker to the command of the Army of the Potomac has given the most sincere gratification to the army, and that even in Washington, where opinions are so diversified that a contrary sentiment has been rarely expressed, and then only by the sympathize with Generals of that character altogether in command, that personal bickerings and misunderstandings may be avoided, and once be obtained.

The chargeable of Sumner and Franklin are that they have remoted as active demoralization of the army.
Both probably be court A thorough reorganization of the troops will be made before offensive operations are resumed.
The men are rapidly being said, in hope of arresting the prevalent spirit of .

Another statement is, that Gens, Sumner and Franklin were relieved from their commands of the right and left grand divisions in consequence of their refusal to fight under Hooker, for lack of confidence in his abilities; but the names of their successors have not been divulged, if appointed.

Gen. Burnside, with most of his staff, have been allowed 30 days leave of absence.
They will go to New York.

A dispatch from Cairo, dated the 22d, says Col. R. C. Murphy has been dismissed from the service for the surrender of Holly Springs. Gen. Asboth, one of Fremon's men, has taken the place of Gen. Davies, who was superceded for a surrender similar to that of Murphy.
It adds:
The prisoners taken by Gen. McClernand at Arkansas Post, numbering 4,720 arrived here yesterday, laden in suffocating masses upon three river steamers.

Gen. McArthur's division moved from Memphis Southward, by the river, on the 19th, and four or five other divisions, including Generals Quinby's and McPherson's, are preparing to move, transports having been engaged for the purpose.
It is generally believed that this movement will be directed against Vicksburg.

Gen. Grant has been down the river, and held a conference with other Generals, and returned to Memphis.
He is now preparing to take command of the expedition personally, and rumor has it that he will supercede Gen. McClernand.
Cotton is reported as coming into Memphis quite freely.

On Monday last the new Finance bill passed the United States House of Representatives.
It authorizes the Secretary of the Treasury to borrow $300,000,000 for the current fiscal year, and $800,000,000 for the next fiscal year, on six per cent. bonds, payable after thirty years in coin, the Secretary to dispose of the bonds on whatever terms he deems advisable.
The Secretary is likewise empowered to issue $400,000,000 of three years Treasury notes, bearing interest payable in coin to be issued in sums as low as ten dollars when desired, receivable for all dues except duties on imposts, and convertible into legal tender notes.
The Secretary of the Treasury is so authorized, "If required by the exigencies of the public service, " to issue $300,000,000 of legal tender notes similar to those now in circulation.

The official terms of the Assistant Secretaries of War, Watson and Turker, expired last Wednesday.
Mr. Watson alone will be retained in the Department, which will be reorganized by the appointment of Solicitor to the War Department, a position to which Mr. Whiting will be appointed, with Robert Dale Owen as a Special Commissioner.

The Common Council of New York city has passed resolutions respecting the dismissal of General Fitz John Porter, rebuking the Administration, and promised by the statement that it views with alarm the removal from the service of the United States of a General who has been and still is regarded by the people "as the very personification of all that is brave, loyal, and patriotic."--The resolutions tender General Porter the use of the Governor's room for a public reception, and denounce the Court Martial as the packed instrument of gross injustice.
The Washington telegrams announcing the resignations of Burnside, Sumner, and Franklin, created a profound sensation in Wall street.

div3.head: Yankee Generals resigned — position of Affairs in the West.
div3.p: --The Advertiser and Register has received a dispatch dated Jackson, January 29, which says:

q.p: Parties who have arrived here from Memphis state that Gen. Huriout, of Illinois, commanding at that point, and Gen. Willard, of Ohio, have resigned in consequence of Lincoln's emancipation proclamation.

div3.p:
It is reported that Corinth has been reinforced to the number of eight thousand.
There are no Federal forces south of Corinth or Grand Junction.
The Federals continue marœwring opposite and below Vicksburg but an early engagement in that vicinity is regarded as very doubtful.
New Orleans papers contain nothing of interest, save a report of the capture of Vicksburg.

div3.head: Reported capture of Holly Springs by the Confederates.
div3.p:
--It is reported that Gen. Van-Dorn has recaptured Holly Springs Miss., with seven hundred prisoners and a considerable quantity of army rations.
A Michigan cavalry regiment is said to have been out to pieces in the charge.

div3.head: Surrender of a Federal gunboat and crew.
div3.p:
--The Federal gunboat John P. Smith, carrying eleven guns and two hundred men, surrendered unconditionally to our forces this afternoon, after a sharp engagement in Stone river.
The enemy's loss is heavy.
Only one man was wounded on our side.
Another gunboat escaped in a crippled condition.
Our forces were under the command of Lieut. Col. Yates.

div3.head: From Charleston.
div3.p: --Our scouts report that Pinckney, Dawlaskie, and Ball's Islands have been evacuated by the enemy.
Forty-seven anti vessels are reported at Hilton Head.

Heavy firing has been heard in the direction of Stone this morning, which lasted several hours.
It is believed, however, to be nothing more than the enemy practicing at target on Cole's Island.

div4.p: On the 23rd inst, by the Rev. J. L. Burrows, at the residence of the bride's father, in Hanover county, Mr. Geo. H. Richards, of this city, and Miss. Mary E. Johnson.

At the residence of the bride's father, on the 14th of January, 1863, by the Rev. James E. Gates, Mr. James Reith, of South Carolina, member of Courtney's artillery, to Miss. Mary C. Blay-Lock, of Richmond.
South Carolina papers please copy.
At his residence, on Oregon Hill, on the morning of the 29th instant, after a painful and protracted illness, in the 23d year of his age, Mr. Levi W. Miller.

in all the relations sustained in life he was highly esteemed and loved.
In obedience to his country's call, in the morning of the present struggle, he volunteered to help fight her battles.
In the defence of this city, near Malvern Hill, last summer, he received a wound, which, with the natural infirmities of his system, resulted in his death.
In making this sad record, it is pleasing to add--

lg.l: "he sleeps in Jesus and is blest--
how sweet his slumbers are!"

div4.p:
for several days before his death he was triumphant in the faith of the Gospel of Christ.
He left, for the consolation of his numerous friends and relatives, the assurance that death would be his eternal gain.
His assurance enables his afflicted and devoted sisters, in the spirit of resignation, to say--

lg.l: "Dearest brother, thou hast left us,
We thy loss most deeply feel;
But his Son who hath bereft us,
He can all our sorrows heal."

div4.p:
He leaves behind a young and devoted wife, to mourn with his mother, sisters and other relatives, their irreparable loss.
May God give them grace for this their day of sorrow!

His funeral sermon, and his father's also, who was killed in the battle of Sharpsburg, will be preached in the Baptist Church, Oregon Hill, this morning at 11 o'clock. Their friends and the friends of the family are invited to attend. *
on the 30th inst, at quarter to 4 o'clock, after a long and painful Pines, Mrs. Elizabeth Moore, consort of Mr. Wm. Moore, in the 64th year of her age.

lg.l: A light is from our household gone,
A voice we loved is stilled,
A place is vacant at our hearth
Which never can be filled.
A gentle heart, that throbbed but now
With tenderness and love,
Has hushed its weary throbbing here,
To throb in bliss above,
Yes, to the home where angels are
Her turning soul has fled,
And yet we bond above the tomb
With tears, and call her dead
We call her dead; but, and we know
She dwells where living waters flow.

div4.p: The friends and acquaintances of the family, and those of her son, Abner C. Moore, are requested to attend her funeral, from the Baptist Church in Manchester, at 11 o'clock to-morrow (Sunday) morning, without further notice.
On Friday morning, Jan. 30th, in the city of Richmond, George Mason, youngest child of John and Anna M. Ambler, of Fauquier county, aged one year and fifteen days.

The funeral will take place to-day, (Saturday,) at 1 o'clock, from the residence of Capt. Wm. G. Lloyd, extreme end of Grace street, West.
The friends and acquaintances of his father and mother are invited to attend.
At Pantops, Albemarle county, Va., of diphtheria, on the 20th inst., in the 15th year of her age, Margaret Douglas, daughter of M. L., and Eliza M. L. Anderson.
on the 29th inst., after a painful illness Susienewell, youngest daughter of John A., and Julia Dansey, aged 3 years 11 months and 16 days.

lg.l: Susie, again we hope to meet thee,
When the day of life is fled;
Then in Heaven with joy to greet thee,
Where no farewell tear is shed.

div3.head: Twenty five Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--"The Army Depot of the Young Men's Christian Association, in this city, was broken open on Tuesday night last and robbed of about #300 worth of supplies deposited there for the benefit of our soldiers.
This is surely the lowest depth of crime, and exhibits and existence of human depravity in the capital which almost staggers belief."--Whig. Annexed is a list of the articles stolen, as nearly as can be ascertained: A bale of Blankets and Shoes, sent for Jackson's troops; the contents of a Handtruck left at the depot, supposed to be Clothing; a Bundio, supposed to be Clothing, for Capt Buckner Randolph, 49th Virginia Regiment; five or six pairs shoes, among which were one pair men's brogans, No. 12, one pair men's Monroes, No. 11, one ditto, (odd,) Nos 8 and 10; a lot of Tea, mixed, (green and black;) one piece (20 yds.) Bleached Cotton a good deal soiled on outside 5 pounds, or bundles, Black Patent Three (coarse) 6 Hair Brushes and Redding Com's, and a small quantity of Castile Soap.
The above reward will be paid for the recovery of the goods, or for information that will lead to the detection of the thieves.

She has been Richmond.
Her mother, named Charlotte, is hired out by E. D. Each, General Agent.
I will give the above reward to any one, black or white, who will deliver her to me at my residence, in Henrico county, confine her in jail, or inform me where she is, so that I can get her.

div3.head: The Sinking of the Batters.
div3.p:
It is impractical that the Florida could have been the vessel that took the United States gunboat Batters, as she did not leave Mobile until the night of the 18th instant, and the Batters was sunk on Sunday, the 11th inst. It was rumored in this city yesterday — and the rumor came from quite a "reliable source"--that information had been received here that the vessel that did sink her really was the British man-of-war Spitfire, as her Captain indicated in his reply to the hall of the Yankee commander.
The latest Northern papers do not say anything about the Alabama having been the ship; but merely say the damage was done by a vessel "claiming to be the Spitfire. " It may be that Com. Wilkes had wearied out British endurance by his extraordinary blockade of Nassau and other ports, and that orders had been issued which resulted in the decisive naval engagement which has occurred.

div3.head: Yankee Atrocity — Murder of a minister.
div3.p:
A telegram was received in this city yesterday, from Harrisonburg, stating that the Rev. Dr. A. H. Boyd, of Winchester, was murdered in that town on Friday last by the Yankee.
The dispatch does not give any of the particulars connected with this deed of infamy, but merely states that it occurred on the day mentioned.
Dr. B. was a popular and highly esteemed minister of the New School Presbyterian Church, and a gentleman of irreproachable character.

div3.head: Affairs in Kentucky.
div3.p:
A gentleman who recently arrived at Knoxville, Tenn., from Kentucky, furnishes the Register, of that city, with some account of Gen. Woolford's speech at Lebanon, a notice of which has reached us by telegraph.
He says that after disbanding his cavalry Gen. Woolford said that if Lincoln would modify his emancipation proclamation within twenty days he, (Woolford,) if forced again to take up arms, would fight for the South; which announcement was enthusiastically cheered by the men, who term him the "Morgan of the North."
Col. John M. Harian in command of the forces at Lebanon, was present and after the meeting expressed his approbation of Woolford's course.

The Federal force at Danville, when the Register's information was there, numbered about 4,000--A brigade, detached from that town, en route to Frankfort, passing through Harrisburg and Lawrenceburg, stole over 250 negroes.
An old man named McLain (father in-law of Dr. Eastland,) followed this thieving brigade to Frankfort to reclaim his negroes, but on reaching the camp of the contraband was brutally beaten and otherwise, maltreated by the white Abolition commander.

At Lexington the private houses are all occupied as hospitals.
Mrs. Tom Bullen's house, a fine residence was completely ruined by the vandals.
The Register says our information met Carter with his force, twelve miles this side of Lebanon, just returning from his East Tennessee raid; but has no opportunity to hear his report.
The people of the Flue Grass region are represented as being a unit for the Southern Confederacy, and looking anxiously for the return of our army to relieve them from the Abolition despotism.
There is no question that a great revolution in public sentiment has occurred, not only in Kentucky, but in the Northwestern States, since the publication of the emancipation proclamation.

div3.head: The bombardment of Fort McAllister.
div3.p: The bombardment of Fort McAllister, at Genesis Point, (which is the mouth of the Ogeechee river and lies about fifteen miles south of the mouth or the Savannah river,) lasted from 7 o'clock until 12½ o'clock, on the 27th inst. Only one iron-clad was engaged, and the turret was so badly damaged that she was forced to haul off. The Savannah Republican says:

q.p:
The iron-clad Yankee steamer came up in fine style, squared herself for a fight, and after dipping her colors thrice opened upon the battery.
She sat very low in the water, and but little more than her turret could be seen.
Our solid shot are sale to have broken to pieces as they struck her sides.--The other iron-clad lay farther down, round the band in the river, with the wooden vessels, the position enabling them to cross fire on the fort.
The shots were fired at intervals of two or three minutes. The balls from the turret were 11 and 15 inch.

div3.p:
We learn that four vessels, apparently transports, were lying yesterday in Bear river, below Kilkenny, about twelve miles from the point — They probably contain troops, with the intention.
If possible of making a landing in the rear.
There were some one hundred and sixty Government, negroes at work at the battery, who were sent into the interior Monday night, as soon as it was ascertained that the enemy were coming up.

John R. Edmunds, Esq., of Halifax, recently presented to the Court of that county, for distribution among the families of soldiers fifteen thousand pounds of bacon, worth some ten thousand dollars besides making a benevolent disposition of an additional quantity.
We are informed that Mr. H. has, from the very beginning of the war, been constant in making liberal provision for the families of the soldiers themselves, and has made many munificent donations for the benefit of the soldiers and the support of the war. Early in the war he clothed and equipped a company.
His benefactions have been frequent, and as quietly as they were generously performed.

div3.head: The sailing of the Florida.
div3.p:
--A Mobile correspondent of the Charleston Mercury gives the following account of the delay in sailing of the C. S. steamer Florida from that port and her final escape.
It appears that the announcement in the Richmond papers some days ago, that she had sailed was premature.
At that time no effort had been made to run her out:

Captain Maffit lingered here so long after his vessel was ready for sea as to call upon himself much criticism and censure, and applications from some quarter went on to the Secretary of the Navy, requesting his removal from the command of his vessel.
The at once issued the order relieving him from command.
President Davis was then absent from Richmond, and the Secretary acted on his own counsel in the matter; but, happily for Maffit, President Davis arrived in Mobile almost simultaneously with the order of the secretary.--The facts of the delay were explained to the President, who at once restored Maffit to the vessel.

I saw him one night when be was bidding adieu to his friends.
He said that the weather indicates a strong "northeaster," for which he had been waiting so long and that he would be off in a few hours.
But the indication was not fulfilled.
The weather changed, and he remained until last Thursday, the 14th instant when he escaped just before day. He attempted it on the night previous, but the blockaders discovered him and signalied when he withdrew.
Thursday night at very dark.--There was a strong blow and a hall-storm during several hours.
He ran out unobserved.
But about four hours after his escape, they either discovered or suspected that he was gone, and the swiftest steamer among them went to sea, apparently in pursuit.
She will hardly catch him. The Florida is a splendid vessel, in perfect running and fighting thin, and can, probably, whip any craft that she cannot out-ran.

div3.head: From Middle Tennessee.
div3.p: --The Shelbyville Parker, of the 22d inst., has the following interesting intelligence from Middle Tennessee:

q.p:
Gen. Wharton advised us yesterday that all was quiet in front of his carefully guarded lines.
We hear the same report from other points in advance of us. The Federate are resting quietly and doing their best to recuperate their shattered ranks — They continue in somewhat grievous straits for the lack of subsistence.
Up to the time of the battle of Murfreesboro they had the Nashville and Chattanooga Railroad running fifteen miles out, but since then Wheeler and Dick McCaun have seriously retarded their operations by destroying a locomotive and construction train and a bridge a few miles this side of Nashville.
The heavy rains of last week also destroyed the railroad bridge across Stone a river, near Murfreesboro', which our forces left standing.

div3.p:
The Abolitionists at Nashville are also suffering from the recent interruption of river navigation at Harreth Shoals.
They have discovered by this time that, though there may be a flood tide in the land, Wheeler and Forrest have a way of their acting river before which both gunboats and steamers must succumb.

We have also positive information that what Gen. John H. left of the Louisville and Nashville in the way of bridges and embankments has been destroyed by the recent heavy ruins.
This is confirmed by the following which we find in the Nashville Dispatch, of the 17th in:

"It is reported that the bridge on the Louisville and Nashville railroad at Pilot Kuch and another North of Gallavin, were injured by the late ruins and high waters.
These injuries have interfered with the running of the trains.

"We understand that the bridge across MillCreek, on the Nashville and that railroad, has been washed away by the high water.
It is also reported that the bridge or Stone's river has been washed away"

div3.head: The Captured dispatches.
div3.p: --The Charleston Mercury, without stating how it gets its information, of the capture of Major Reld Saunders says:

q.p:
It is now stated that he was betrayed by the new of the As soon as the got out of port the crew tied him and for the floor, and delivered him up to the Yankees.
This account for his dispatches not being sent to the

div3.p: Thirty Dollars reward.--A reward of thirty dollars cash will be paid for the arrest and delivery to me of any one of the following near
Louis & a German, with dark complexion, black eye and hair, and about 5 feet 9 inches high, with a slight stoop in the shoulders.
Henry a German, with blue eyes, fair complexion light hair, and about 5 feet 6 inches high.
John Purgell, an Irishman, with blue eyes, gray hair fair complexion, about 5 feet 10 inches high, add about 35 years of age.
Alfred A Herly, blue eyes, dark hair, fair complexion 5 feet 6 inches high, very spare in figure and about 23 years of age.
James L. Hayward, blue eyes, light hair, yellow complexion 5 feet 7 inches high and about 19 years of age.
Henry Brockelman, a German; with blue eyes, light hair fair complexion, 5 feet 10 inches high, and about 49 years of age.

closer.signed: Capt Co. E. 44th Reg. Va. Infantry.

Elijah Campbell, 5 feet 10 inches high, dark skin, and about 23 years old. The above reward will be paid for the of the hours or $100 for the delivery of either one at the City Gas Works, Rockets.

div3.p: Special Orders, No. 12.

XI.
All officers and men now in this city, and not on duty, belonging to the Army of Northern Virginia, will immediately return to their respective regiments and companies.

By command of the Secretary of War.
Jno. Withers,
Assistant Adjutant-General. ja 24--6t

div3.head: Attention, company A.
div3.p:
--All members of Company A, 22d Virginia battalion, (Captain ) now absent from their , are required to report promptly to me in Manchester, on Tuesday next, 3d of February, prepared to return at that time to their company.
Those felling to do so will be advertised and treated as deserters.
div3.closer:
By order of Lieut. Col N. P. Taylor
Thos. Hatcher 2d Lt Co. A.
22d Va batl'n.

div3.head: Deserted.
div3.p: --From my camp, at Varine, about the 5th of November, 1862:
Edgar J. Einstom, 33 years of age 5 feet 10½ inches high, gray eyes light brown hair; light complexion; was born in friends is decent in appearance; has a youthful voice.
G. P. Dungan, 20 years of age; eyes, dark hair; 5 feet 7½ inches, high; in West morelandcounty, Va., by Capt. Sanford.
L. P. Newman, aged 21 years, blue eyes, light hair; dark complexion, 5 feet 7 inches high; enlisted in Richmond county Va., by Lieut. Harwood.
J. H. Brayne, aged 26 years; gray eyes; light hair; dark complexion; 5 feet 5½ inches high; in Westmoreland county, Va., by Capt. and Sandford.
R. W. Melley, aged 15 years; hasal eyes, dark hair; dark complexion; 5 feet 4½ inches high; enlisted in Westmoreland county, Va., by Capt. Sandford.
A. G. King, aged 16 years; gray eyes, dark hair, dark complexion; 5 feet 5½ inches high; enlisted to Westmoreland county, Va., by Capt. Sandford.
Samuel French, aged 21 years; gray eyes; dark hair; dark complexion; 5 feet 6½ inches high enlisted in Westmoreland county, Va., by Capt. Sandford.
The above six men were conscripts, and deserted from my camp, at Varina, Nov'r 13, 1862.

Fred'k (conscript's substitutes,) enlisted at Richmond city, Va., by Lieut. Colonel J. C. Shields, aged about 35 years; hazel eyes dark hair; dark complexion; 5 feet 2 ½ inches high; born in Germany; deserted from camp at Chaffin's farm, Nov'r 23, 1862.
A reward of $30 will be paid for the apprehension of each, if placed in jail, so that I get them.
div3.closer:
G. A. Wallace, Capt. Comp'y F.
59th Va. reg't. Wise Brigade. de 2--ts

div3.head: Twenty-five Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Runaway on the night of the 24th instant, a mulatto named Willis.
He is about good height; thin board between 30 and 35 years of age, quick in his movements, but over speaking unless spoke to, and had on when he went away a drab cost drab pantaloons, and a dark drab hat. He is well acquainted on James river, from Lynchburg to Richmond and on that part touching Albemarle and Buckingham.
He may attempt to pass himself off as a free men, and hire himself to some officer with a view to getting to the enemy, or he may be lurking in the neighborhood of his wife, who belongs to Mr. N. Y. Cabell, of Nelson and I will pay the above reward if he is lodged in any jail so I can get him again.

closer.signed: W. C. Scott, Powhatan C. R.

div3.head: Runaway--$25 reward.
div3.p:
--Ran off from the subscriber, in the city of Richmond, on the 27th inst., a black Girl, about 14 years old, not very good teeth in front.
She was purchased of Mrs. Mary W. Columbia of Caroline county, and may be be making her way back.
I will pay $25 for her arrest and delivery to , Dickinson & Co.

div3.head: One Hundred Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Runaway from the subscriber, on the 28th Dec'r last my negro man Patrick.
He is about 23 years of age, about five feet, seven inches high, very black, large thick lips, this under one turns entirely over, and large feet and hands.
He has been engaged in driving from my farm, in Henrico, to the city of Richmond for several years part.--He may be lurking about the city, or in some of the camps around.
I will give the above reward for his apprehension and return to me.

div3.head: Fifty Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Runaway from the subscriber, on Monday last, a Negro Woman named Kitty, aged 40 years. Kitty is black, of medium height, rather stout, has lost a portion of her front teeth, and her eye teeth projects an as to be quite noticeable.
Kitty was originally from the neighborhood of Louisa Court-House, and may be attempting to make her way back.
She took with her several Linsey dresses and other articles of wearing apparel.
I will give the above reward for her arrest and confinement in jail so that I get her again.

div3.head: Fifty Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Runaway, about the middle of May, 1862, from the subscriber, at that time on a visit to Hanover county, my negro man, named Phil. Phil is about 55 years of age of medium height, has a scar in his forehead, and has lost several of his front teeth.
He is well acquainted in Richmond and vicinity.
I think that he had gotten a forged pass and has hired himself out. The above reward will be paid for his apprehension and delivery to me in jail in Richmond.

div3.head: Two Hundred Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Runaway in the fourth of August, 1861, my negro woman Lies, called Elizabeth Girls, half white, hair inclined to sort large black eyes, tall and straight, a small spot on one side of her face, does not speak very quick when spoken to, about 26 or 30 years old, was formally owned and sold by Mr. Lipscomb, living near Broad Rock.
In the county of Chesterfield.
She may be about in that vicinity, of the town of or the city of Richmond, about which places who is well acquainted.
The above reward of will be paid for her delivery to me at Public Warehouse or secured in any jail so that I get her again.
div3.closer:
B. J. Vaughan.
Richmond, Jan. 8th, 1863. ja 8--2aw4w*

div3.p:
Twenty-five Dollars reward will be paid for the capture and delivery to me of a negro boy named Oscar, who absenced on the 20th January, 1863, from my house, near Richmond, Oscar is about 18 years old; of dark mulatto color; stoutly framed, and has a very and bushy read of hair.
He is specially marked by having lost the end of one middle finger; that the left hand, I believe, but am not which.
He will probably attempt to get to the lines of the Yankee army, near Fredericksburg.
The attention of our army pickets is particularly invited to this notice.

div3.head: One Hundred Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--My negro man, Edmund, about 25 years old, black color, slander form, 5 feet 6 or 7 inches height, ranaway about the 6th inst. Edmund is probably lurking about the city of Richmond, or with Gen Wise's Brigade about Cheffin's farm.
The above reward will be paid for his apprehension and delivery to Hill.
Dickinson & Co. of the city of Richmond.

div3.head: Fifty Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Runaway from the subscriber's Jail, about the 18th inst., a negro Girl, named Cally, about 18 years old, about 5 feet 2 or 3 inches in height; has marks on the side of her neck — another marks re-collected.
She was sold out of Rargrove's estate I think she is recruited in the city.
I will give the above reward on her delivery at my Jail in the city of Richmond.

div3.head: Fifty Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Runaway from the subscriber about the 1st of November last, my negro was Gitarles.
The above reward will be paid to any one who will deliver to me, to my plantation in Halifax county, Depot, on the Richmond and railroad or confine him in some county, jail so that I can get him. He is about 5 feet 11 inches high, ginger-bread color; usually wears his hair plaited and when not plaited has a fell head of hair.
He was bought recently from Col. James W. Twy of Madison county, Va., and it is believed to making his way to his old neighborhood.
My post-office is Whitlock Halifax, Va.

div3.head: Fifty Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Runaway from the subscriber, about two weeks ago, a negro boy named Henry.
Said boy is about sixteen years old, five feet high, round and good no doubt will he is free; has been seen in Richmond in the last few days.
He may have gone to the army.
I will pay the above reward of fifty dollars for his delivery in any jail in the State.

div3.head: Twenty-five Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--I will give the above reward for the apprehension of my boy Charles, who left my premises about the 40th of January.
The said boy is a bright mulatto, about 8 years of age, and was hired last year at the Spotswood Hotel.

div3.head:
Office Richmond & R. R. Co.,
Richmond, Va., Nov. 70th, 1862.
div3.p:
Runaway.--A suitable reward will be paid for the apprehension and delivery of a man named John, who ran away from the company in October last.
John was hired from Mr. H. E. Boomer, of Fredericksburg.
